results.name: A/Prof Giel van Dooren
results.summary: A/Prof Giel van Dooren is an academic affiliated with The University of Melbourne and The Australian National University (ANU). He completed a Bachelor of Arts/Bachelor of Science degree at the University of Melbourne in 2000, studying topics such as Australian history, eukaryotic evolution, creative writing, and cell biology. He earned his PhD at the University of Melbourne, focusing on the evolution, biogenesis, and metabolism of the mitochondrion and apicoplast organelles in the malaria-causing parasite Plasmodium falciparum. Afterward, he worked in Boris Striepen’s lab at the University of Georgia, studying the intracellular parasite Toxoplasma gondii. In 2012, he joined ANU as a lecturer in the Research School of Biology. His research primarily focuses on the cell biology and metabolism of apicomplexan parasites, particularly Toxoplasma gondii, aiming to understand how these parasites acquire nutrients from host cells and how these processes can be targeted for new treatments. results.name: A/Prof Mark Harvey
results.summary: Associate Professor Mark Harvey is a linguist affiliated with The University of Newcastle, Australia. His research focuses on Indigenous Australian languages, particularly their phonology, syntax, and historical relationships. He has led several Australian Research Council (ARC) Discovery Projects, including one that demonstrated all Australian Indigenous languages descend from a common ancestor, Proto-Australian. This groundbreaking study, co-authored with Associate Professor Robert Mailhammer, was published in the journal Diachronica in March 2023. ([newcastle.edu.au](https://www.newcastle.edu.au/newsroom/college-of-human-and-social-futures/indigenous-languages-research-findings-make-global-impact?utm_source=openai)) Another significant project, titled "The Building Blocks of Language: Words in Central Australian Languages," commenced in 2022 and is set to conclude in 2025. ([newcastle.edu.au](https://www.newcastle.edu.au/profile/mark-harvey?utm_source=openai)) Additionally, Harvey has extensively documented the endangered Kaytetye language, aiming to preserve its unique phonological structures and contribute to broader linguistic theories. ([newcastle.edu.au](https://www.newcastle.edu.au/highlights/research/h/marking-the-past?utm_source=openai))

results.name: A/Prof Shih-Chun Lo

results.name: A/Prof Sridhar Ravi
affiliations: The University of New South Wales
results.summary: Associate Professor Sridhar Ravi is the Deputy Head of the School of Engineering and Technology at UNSW Canberra and leads the Bio-Engineering Research Group. His research focuses on biomechanics, bio-mimetics, fluid mechanics, flight control, fluid-structure interaction, compliant actuators, aerial and aquatic locomotion, neuroethology, and collective behaviour. Recent publications include a 2025 journal article on bio-inspired swimming gaits and book chapters on collision avoidance in honeybee flights and bumblebee wing dynamics. He completed his Bachelors of Engineering (Aerospace) and PhD at RMIT University, studying the influence of wind turbulence on wing aerodynamics. Between 2012 and 2014, he was a Post-Doc at Harvard University, studying insect and bird flight in complex environments. From 2015 to 2017, he worked at Chiba University and the University of Bielefeld, focusing on bio-inspired design and neuroethology of flight. Dr. Ravi returned to Australia in 2017 as a Lecturer at RMIT University and joined UNSW Canberra in 2019 as a Senior Lecturer. He has supervised numerous publications, including journal articles, book chapters, conference papers, and preprints. His teaching interests include rotorcraft engineering and fundamentals of flight. He is open to supervising motivated researchers in multi-disciplinary research areas. Contact: sridhar.r@unsw.edu.au

([maths.usyd.edu.au](https://www.maths.usyd.edu.au/u/nathanb/research.html?utm_source=openai))

results.name: Dr Nicholas Hamilton
results.summary: Dr. Nicholas Hamilton is the Institute Bio-Mathematician at the Institute for Molecular Bioscience, The University of Queensland, and holds a co-appointment with the Research Computing Centre at UQ. He specializes in mathematical modeling, machine learning, data visualization, kidney development, cell biology, bio-imaging, and cancer imaging. His research focuses on developing new methodologies in machine learning and artificial intelligence to generate predictive mathematical models, particularly in bio-image informatics and data visualization. He earned a PhD in Pure Mathematics from the University of Western Australia in 1996 and transitioned to computational biology and bioinformatics in 2002. In 2008, he was appointed as a Laboratory Head at IMB, and in 2014, he became the Institute Bio-Mathematician, leading a group in bio-image informatics, mathematical modeling, and data visualization. His research has led to the discovery that the growth of the ureteric tree in the developing kidney follows a consistent pattern, describable by simple mathematical rules similar to the Fibonacci sequence. Recent publications include studies on the ureteric tree's branching morphogenesis and the structure of biological branching. His ultimate goal is to use mathematical modeling to uncover fundamental biological processes, translating these findings into real-world biomedical applications.
results.search_notes: Specific information about Dr. Nicholas Hamilton's research areas, publications, and career highlights was found on the University of Queensland's website.

His research interests are in female reproductive biology, particularly the uterus and implantation of the blastocyst, the evolution of live birth, and female fertility and its complications, especially endometriosis. He has published in these areas since 1979 and continues to publish in a reduced capacity since retirement in 2019. Chris remains on the Editorial Boards of several international journals, including Membranes, Journal of Morphology, and Acta Histochemica. He has been on the Ethics Committee of IVF-Australia since 2012. ([usap.sydney.edu.au](https://usap.sydney.edu.au/emeritus-bosch-professor-chris-murphy/?utm_source=openai))

results.name: Em/Prof Keith Murray
results.summary:
I found information on two individuals named Keith Murray affiliated with Australian institutions:

1. **Emeritus Professor Keith Murray**: Affiliated with Monash University's School of Chemistry, he specializes in molecular magnetism, focusing on single molecule magnets (SMMs) and spin-crossover species. ([monash.edu](https://www.monash.edu/science/schools/chemistry/about-us/our-people/our-people/emeritus-professors?utm_source=openai))

2. **Professor Keith Murray**: Associated with the University of Melbourne's Murray Laboratory, his research centers on the genetic regulation of morphogenesis, particularly epithelial plasticity, using model systems like *Drosophila melanogaster* and cultured human cells. ([murraylab.science.unimelb.edu.au](https://murraylab.science.unimelb.edu.au/?utm_source=openai))

Both have notable academic backgrounds and contributions in their respective fields.

Ryan's contributions were recognized with numerous accolades, including being named a Member of the Order of Australia in 2019. results.name: Em/Prof Mike Daube
results.summary: Professor Mike Daube is an Emeritus Professor in the Faculty of Health Sciences at Curtin University, where he was a Professor of Health Policy and Director of the Public Health Advocacy Institute. He has been a leading figure in national and international action and research on tobacco, alcohol, gambling, and other public health issues for several decades. ([tobacco-vape-research.org.au](https://www.tobacco-vape-research.org.au/glow_team/emeritus-prof-mike-daube/?utm_source=openai)) He has been President of the Australian Council on Smoking and Health, and the Public Health Association of Australia, Chair of the Australian Government’s Tobacco Expert Committee that recommended tobacco plain packaging, chair or member of many further national and international committees and organizations and remains active on tobacco issues, including with the World Health Organization, where he is a member of the Tobacco Regulation committee. ([emedevents.com](https://www.emedevents.com/speaker-profile/mike-daube-ao?utm_source=openai))

results.name: Em/Prof Myron Zalucki
results.summary: Emeritus Professor Myron Zalucki is an Australian entomologist specializing in insect ecology, particularly focusing on insect-plant interactions within the order Lepidoptera. He has made significant contributions to understanding the ecology of insects, including studies on monarch butterflies and crop pests like Helicoverpa armigera and Plutella xylostella. His recent publications in 2025 cover topics such as the genetic basis of migratory diapause in Australian monarch butterflies and the impact of land use on aphid-parasitoid-hyperparasitoid food webs. He holds a Bachelor of Science with first-class honors from the Australian National University and a Ph.D. in ecology from Griffith University. He has been a Fellow of the Entomological Society of America since 2018 and received the Ian MacKerras Medal for excellence in Entomology from the Australian Entomological Society in 1996.

results.name: Prof Aihua Xia
results.summary: Prof. Aihua Xia is a Professor in the School of Mathematics and Statistics at the University of Melbourne. She holds a PhD from the University of Melbourne and is currently the Chair of Optometry Research at the University of Western Australia and the Lions Eye Institute. Her research focuses on improving clinical tests for measuring and monitoring vision disorders, with specific interests in glaucoma, diabetic eye disease, macular disorders, and age-related changes to vision. ([lei.org.au](https://www.lei.org.au/research/scientists/professor-allison-mckendrick/?utm_source=openai))
results.search_notes: While Professor McKendrick is affiliated with the University of Melbourne, there is no evidence from the available sources that she is currently affiliated with the Queensland University of Technology.

results.name: Prof Allison Waters
results.summary: Professor Allison Waters is a clinical psychologist and program director at Griffith University's Childhood Anxiety Disorders Research Program. Her research focuses on childhood anxiety disorders, including the development and evaluation of cognitive-behavioral therapy interventions. She has authored numerous publications on topics such as attention bias modification and the neural mechanisms underlying anxiety in children. Specific information regarding her affiliations with The University of Western Australia and Queensland University of Technology is not readily available.

results.name: Prof Anatoli Kheifets
results.summary: Professor Anatoli Kheifets is an Emeritus Professor at The Australian National University (ANU), specializing in atomic and molecular physics, particularly in the areas of atomic ionization in super-strong laser fields, coherent control of quantum-mechanical systems, and attosecond time-resolved atomic reactions. He has been involved in several significant projects, including the study of atomic double ionization by electron and heavy ion impact, and the development of time-space resolved photoelectron emission to control molecular processes. His recent publications include works on Wigner time delay in atomic photoionization and shape resonances in photoionization cross sections and time delay.

results.name: Prof Andrew Eberhard
results.summary: Professor Andrew Eberhard is a Deputy Head of the Department of Mathematical and Geospatial Sciences at RMIT University. He specializes in optimization theory and algorithms, focusing on continuous, nonsmooth optimization and integer programming. His recent work includes developing algorithms for stochastic optimization problems involving integer variables. He has applied his research to areas such as control theory, nonsmooth optimality conditions, and the theory of viscosity solutions of elliptic partial differential equations. He has also worked on the Feasibility Pump for Mixed Integer Programming and provided convergence analysis of progressive hedging for stochastic optimization problems involving integer variables. Additionally, he has applied convex and functional analysis to control design and signal processing problems. He has an interest in monotone operator theory and convex analysis. He has supervised various research projects, including enhancing machine learning model performance through advanced hyperparameter and topology optimization techniques, reboot sensing MIMO with machine learning and mathematical optimization, and improving air traffic flow optimization using weather information. He has also supervised projects on frames of fractals, constrained DC optimization in clustering, and non-convex optimization using a finite-time dynamics approach. He has been an invited speaker at various conferences, including the Variational and Nonsmooth Analysis conference at The Hong Kong Polytechnic University in December 2024 and the International Conference on Applied Mathematics in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, in July 2024. He has also served as the co-chair for optimization of the AustMS special interest group, Mathematics of Computational and Optimization (MoCaO) from 2018 to 2024. results.name: Prof Cecil Coady
affiliations: The University of New South Wales
results.summary: I was unable to find specific information about an academic researcher named "Prof Cecil Coady" affiliated with The University of Melbourne, Charles Sturt University, Monash University, or The University of New South Wales. However, there is a notable Australian philosopher named Cecil Anthony John Coady, commonly known as C. A. J. Coady, who has made significant contributions to epistemology and political philosophy. He is best known for his work on the epistemological problems posed by testimony, particularly in his book "Testimony: A Philosophical Study" (Oxford University Press, 1990). Coady has also published extensively on issues related to political violence and has been a regular commentator in the Australian media on philosophical aspects of public affairs. He has held academic positions at the University of Melbourne, including lecturer, reader, and Boyce Gibson Professor, and has been involved in various visiting positions worldwide. Coady has received several honors, including being elected a Fellow of the Australian Academy of the Humanities in 1994 and awarded the Centenary of Federation Medal in 2001. He has also been recognized with the T. G. Tucker Medal for outstanding achievements and excellence in scholarship at the University of Melbourne in 2015. His selected publications include "Testimony: A Philosophical Study" (1995), "Morality and Political Violence" (2007), "Messy Morality: The Challenge of Politics" (2009), and "The Meaning of Terrorism" (2021).

His research interests include computational geomechanics, unsaturated soils, transport geotechnics, and environmental geotechnics. He has developed novel computer models to address practical problems such as embankments on soft soils, high-speed rail geotechnical issues, and cold region geotechnical challenges. He is an elected Fellow of the Australian Academy of Technology and Engineering (FTSE).
results.search_notes: Information about Professor Sheng's research areas, publications, and career highlights was found through multiple sources, including his profiles at UTS and the Australian Academy of Technology and Engineering.

results.name: Prof Dale Godfrey
results.summary: Prof. Dale Godfrey is a male immunologist affiliated with The University of Melbourne and Monash University. He has over 25 years of experience in T cell biology, focusing on T cell development and innate-like T cell biology, particularly Natural Killer T (NKT) cells and Mucosal Associated Invariant T (MAIT) cells. He has published approximately 170 papers and has been involved in significant research projects, including the development of SARS-CoV-2 vaccines. He is also the current President of the Australasian Society for Immunology.
results.search_notes: Found detailed information on Prof. Godfrey's research areas, publications, and achievements.

results.name: Prof Damian Dowling
results.summary: Professor Damian Dowling is an evolutionary ecologist at Monash University's School of Biological Sciences. His research focuses on mitochondrial genome evolution, oxidative stress, and sexually antagonistic coevolution. He has led several projects, including 'Unlocking the secrets of the mitochondrion' and 'Unravelling the role of heteroplasmy in mitochondrial adaptation'. His work has been recognized by the Knut and Alice Wallenberg Foundation, which awarded him a Wallenberg Academy Fellowship in 2012. ([research.monash.edu](https://research.monash.edu/en/persons/damian-dowling?utm_source=openai), [damiandowlinglab.org](https://damiandowlinglab.org/?utm_source=openai), [kaw.wallenberg.org](https://kaw.wallenberg.org/en/damian-dowling?utm_source=openai))
results.search_notes: Information about Professor Dowling's research areas, recent publications, and career highlights was found on Monash University's website and other reputable sources.

results.name: Prof Damien Keating
results.summary: Professor Damien Keating is a male academic researcher affiliated with Flinders University in Adelaide, Australia. He serves as the Deputy Director of the Flinders Health and Medical Research Institute and leads the Molecular and Cellular Physiology research group. His research focuses on understanding how cells communicate through chemical signals, particularly in the gut, and how these processes relate to health and disease, including metabolic disorders like diabetes and obesity. He has published significant work in leading international journals such as Nature, PNAS, and PLoS Genetics. ([flinders.edu.au](https://www.flinders.edu.au/people/damien.keating?utm_source=openai))

results.name: Prof Danny Liew
results.summary: Professor Danny Liew is a consultant physician and academic leader specializing in clinical epidemiology, health services research, and health economics. He currently serves as the Dean and Head of the Adelaide Medical School at the University of Adelaide, a position he has held since January 2022. Prior to this, he was the Chair of Clinical Epidemiology and Director of the Melbourne EpiCentre at the University of Melbourne from 2010 to 2015. His recent research includes studies on the cost-effectiveness of non-statin lipid-lowering drugs for cardiovascular disease in patients with type 2 diabetes and the health and economic burden of cardiovascular disease among people with type 2 diabetes. He has also been involved in projects related to chronic heart disease and its co-morbid complications. Additionally, he has served as a speaker, consultant, and advisory board member for several pharmaceutical companies, including AbbVie, AstraZeneca, and Pfizer. ([adelaide.edu.au](https://www.adelaide.edu.au/newsroom/news/list/2021/10/14/new-dean-and-head-of-adelaide-medical-school?utm_source=openai), [health.adelaide.edu.au](https://health.adelaide.edu.au/news/list/2023/12/06/connected-conversations-danny-liew?utm_source=openai), [about.uq.edu.au](https://about.uq.edu.au/experts/48735?utm_source=openai), [onlinelibrary.wiley.com](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/apt.14955?utm_source=openai), [research.monash.edu](https://research.monash.edu/en/projects/novel-approaches-to-the-prevention-and-treatment-of-chronic-heart?utm_source=openai))

results.name: Prof David Day
results.summary: Professor David Day is an Emeritus Professor at Flinders University, Australia, with a distinguished career in plant biochemistry and molecular biology. His work has been featured in SPIE Newsroom, highlighting the potential of optical coherence elastography to enhance cancer surgery efficiency. results.name: Prof Dr Da-Wei Wang

results.summary: Prof. Dr. Da-Wei Wang is an Associate Professor in the School of Chemical Engineering at the University of New South Wales (UNSW), Australia. His research focuses on the chemistry and synthesis of high-performance energy materials, as well as the design of next-generation renewable energy conversion and storage devices, including supercapacitors, metal/sulfur batteries, metal-ion batteries, aqueous redox flow batteries, and fuel cells. He has contributed over 100 journal publications, 8 patents, and more than 20 keynote/invited presentations, with over 13,000 citations and an H-index of 40. Prof. Wang has received several prestigious awards, including the 2012 Fundamental Research Excellence Award from the University of Queensland and the 2013 Scopus Young Researcher Award in Engineering and Technology. results.name: Prof Dr Jacob Goeree
affiliations: The University of New South Wales
results.summary: Prof. Dr. Jacob Goeree is a Dutch economist and Scientia Professor at the UNSW Business School. He specializes in experimental economics, focusing on market design, auction theory, and game theory. His research has significantly influenced the design of major spectrum auctions worldwide, including the 700MHz auction in the U.S. that generated record revenues of $19 billion. He has also co-designed the market for pollution permits for the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative. Goeree has published in top journals such as Econometrica, the American Economic Review, and the Journal of Political Economy. He holds a PhD in Economics from the University of Amsterdam and a PhD in Theoretical Physics from the University of Utrecht. Prior to joining UNSW, he was a full professor at Caltech and the University of Zurich. In 2018, he was elected a Fellow of the Academy of the Social Sciences in Australia. His work has been recognized with awards from the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences and the Econometric Society. His most cited works include "Ten Little Treasures of Game Theory and Ten Intuitive Contradictions," "Quantal Response Equilibrium and Overbidding in Private-Value Auctions," and "A Theoretical Analysis of Altruism and Decision Error in Public Goods Games."
results.search_notes: Comprehensive information about Prof. Dr. Jacob Goeree's research areas, publications, and academic background was found through web search.

results.name: Prof Dr Mohammed Bennamoun

results.name: Prof Geoffrey Faulkner
results.summary: Professor Geoffrey Faulkner is a computational and molecular biologist at the University of Queensland, specializing in transposable elements, genomics, and neuroscience. He leads the Genome Plasticity and Disease research group at Mater Research, focusing on the role of L1 retrotransposons in genetic mosaicism in neurons and their implications in neurological diseases and cancer. ([materresearch.org.au](https://www.materresearch.org.au/researchers/our-researchers/find-a-researcher/prof-geoffrey-faulkner?utm_source=openai))

results.name: Prof Geoffrey Goodhill
results.summary: Professor Geoffrey Goodhill is a computational neuroscientist with a diverse academic background, including degrees in Mathematics, Physics, Artificial Intelligence, and Cognitive Science. He has held faculty positions at institutions such as Georgetown University and the University of Queensland, and currently serves as a Professor of Neuroscience and Developmental Biology at Washington University School of Medicine. His research focuses on understanding the computational principles underlying brain development, particularly in areas like axon guidance, visual map formation, and neural coding. He has published over 130 papers and has been awarded numerous grants from organizations like the NIH, NSF, and the Australian Research Council. ([neuroscience.wustl.edu](https://neuroscience.wustl.edu/people/geoffrey-goodhill-phd/?utm_source=openai), [goodhill.org](https://goodhill.org/bio.html?utm_source=openai))

([neuroscience.wustl.edu](https://neuroscience.wustl.edu/people/geoffrey-goodhill-phd/?utm_source=openai), [goodhill.org](https://goodhill.org/bio.html?utm_source=openai))

results.name: Prof Geoffrey McFadden
results.summary: Professor Geoffrey McFadden is a parasitologist and evolutionary biologist at the University of Melbourne. He has conducted extensive research on malaria parasites, particularly focusing on the apicoplast, a relict chloroplast, leading to new drug development strategies. He established Australia's first malaria life cycle facility and mosquito insectary, funded by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation and the Malaria Vaccine Initiative. ([figshare.unimelb.edu.au](https://figshare.unimelb.edu.au/authors/GEOFFREY_MCFADDEN/1102844?utm_source=openai))

results.name: Prof Geordie Williamson
results.summary: Professor Geordie Williamson is an Australian mathematician specializing in geometric representation theory. He has made significant contributions to the field, including the development of Hodge theory for Soergel bimodules and a proof of the Kazhdan-Lusztig conjectures for general Coxeter groups. In 2018, he was elected as the youngest living Fellow of the Royal Society at the age of 36. In 2023, he was awarded an Australian Laureate Fellowship to further his research into fundamental symmetries. ([arc.gov.au](https://www.arc.gov.au/funding-research/funding-schemes/discovery-program/australian-laureate-fellowships/2023-laureate-profile-professor-geordie-williamson?utm_source=openai))

results.name: Prof Georges Grau
results.summary: Professor Georges Grau is a male academic affiliated with the University of Sydney. He holds an MD from the University of Liège and a Privat-Docent from the University of Genève. Since 2006, he has been the Chair of Vascular Immunology at the University of Sydney, focusing on immunopathological mechanisms of infectious diseases, particularly cerebral malaria, septic shock, and multiple sclerosis. His research emphasizes cytokines, the microvascular endothelium, and extracellular vesicles. He has published over 400 papers, cited more than 40,000 times, with an h-index of 103. He served as Discipline Leader (Pathology) at the Marie Bashir Institute from 2015 to 2021 and was re-elected President of the Australian-New Zealand Microcirculation Society in 2021.

results.name: Prof Gerard Docherty
results.summary: Professor Gerard Docherty is the Dean (Research) in the Arts, Education and Law Group at Griffith University. He holds a Bachelor of Arts with Honours and a PhD from the University of Edinburgh. His research focuses on the quantitative acoustic analysis of speech, particularly phonetic variability and its social implications. He has supervised doctoral projects in sociophonetics, descriptive and theoretical phonetics, and clinical phonetics. He was recently a Chief Investigator on an ARC-funded Discovery Project titled 'The social dynamics of language: a study of phonological variation and change in West Australian English'.

results.name: Prof Javen Qinfeng Shi
results.summary: Professor Javen Qinfeng Shi is the Founding Director of the Causal AI Group at the University of Adelaide and serves as a director at the Australian Institute for Machine Learning. His research interests encompass causation, artificial intelligence, and metaphysics. He has applied his research across various industries, including material discovery, agriculture, mining, sports, manufacturing, bushfire management, health, and education. Notably, he secured first place at the Open Catalyst Challenge at NeurIPS AI for Science 2023, utilizing AI for energy material discovery, and won the AUS/NZ Bushfire Data Quest 2020 by predicting fire spread with AI, leading to the development of the NOBURN bushfire app in 2023, which received over 50 media coverages. Additionally, he achieved second place in the Explorer Challenge 2019 and first place at SAIC Volkswagen’s Logistics Innovation Day for Smart Manufacturing 2019. His Google Scholar rankings place him 7th globally in probabilistic graphical models and 4th in causation. He has also served as a panellist for the Responsible AI Think Tank from 2022 to 2024 and currently holds a position on the AI Industry Forum from 2024 onward, contributing to the development of the national and state AI ecosystem. He has authored over 620 peer-reviewed publications and secured more than $26 million in competitive external funding. His research has been recognized with a Fulbright Senior Scholarship and leadership roles in various health associations. ([uts.edu.au](https://www.uts.edu.au/about/faculties/health/public-health/who-we-are/our-leaders-and-staff?utm_source=openai))
research_areas: Public health and health services research
results.search_notes: Information about Professor Jon Adams is available from multiple reputable sources, including the University of Technology Sydney and The Conversation.

results.name: Prof Jonathan Corcoran
results.summary: Professor Jonathan Corcoran is a researcher affiliated with the University of Queensland, specializing in urban studies and transportation. His recent work includes analyzing urban heat island effects using machine learning and examining the impact of COVID-19 on Australian short-term rental markets. ([chemeng.uq.edu.au](https://chemeng.uq.edu.au/profile/6131/jonathan-corcoran?utm_source=openai))
research_areas: machine learning applications in urban planning
results.search_notes: Specific information about Professor Corcoran's affiliations with Griffith University and RMIT University was not found in the available sources.

results.name: Prof Jonathan Evans
results.summary: Professor Jonathan Evans is a marine biologist at The University of Western Australia, specializing in sexual selection and evolutionary biology. His research primarily focuses on sexual selection, sperm competition, and evolutionary and ecological genetics in natural and laboratory populations of freshwater fishes and marine invertebrates. He has held various academic positions at UWA, including Associate Professor and currently Professor in the School of Biological Sciences. His research is funded by multiple Australian Research Council (ARC) Discovery Projects, focusing on mechanisms underlying chemical signaling in the sea and the dynamics of sexual selection in broadcast spawners. He has also served on the editorial board of the Proceedings of the Royal Society London B and as a consulting editor for Animal Behaviour. His teaching includes courses on Behavioural Ecology, Evolutionary Processes, and Field Studies in Zoology. His work contributes to the UN Sustainable Development Goals, particularly in areas related to marine life conservation and sustainable use of oceans. His research expertise includes behavioural ecology, evolutionary biology, fish biology and behaviour, sperm competition, genital evolution, gamete evolution, and mating systems.
results.search_notes: Found detailed information on Professor Jonathan Evans' research areas, academic background, and career highlights from The University of Western Australia's official profiles and research repository.

results.name: Prof Jonathan Horner
results.summary: Professor Jonti Horner is an astrophysicist at the University of Southern Queensland, specializing in astrobiology, solar system formation, exoplanets, and planetary habitability. He has contributed to several publications, including studies on planetesimal evolution and the GALAH survey. He holds an MSc from Durham University and a PhD from the University of Oxford. ([staffprofile.unisq.edu.au](https://staffprofile.unisq.edu.au/Profile/Jonti-Horner?utm_source=openai), [research.usq.edu.au](https://research.usq.edu.au/researcher/80zz5/prof-jonti-horner?utm_source=openai))
results.search_notes: Information about Professor Jonti Horner's research areas, publications, and academic background was found on the University of Southern Queensland's website.

results.name: Prof Jonathan Manton
results.summary: Professor Jonathan Manton is an Australian electrical engineer and academic, currently holding a Distinguished Chair at the University of Melbourne and serving as a Future Generation Professor in Electrical and Electronic Engineering. He is also an Adjunct Professor at the Australian National University. His research interests encompass mathematical systems theory, including signal processing and optimization, as well as geometry and topology, both differential and algebraic. Additionally, he explores learning and computation, with applications in systems biology, neuroscience, and machine learning. Professor Manton has been recognized as a Fellow of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE) in 2016 for his contributions to geometric methods in signal processing and wireless communications. He has also served as an Associate Editor for the IEEE Transactions on Signal Processing and a Lead Guest Editor for the IEEE Transactions on Selected Topics in Signal Processing. His academic background includes a Bachelor of Science (mathematics) and Bachelor of Engineering (electrical) degrees in 1995, followed by a Ph.D. in 1998, all from the University of Melbourne. In 2005, he became a full Professor in the Research School of Information Sciences and Engineering at the Australian National University. From mid-2006 to mid-2008, he was on secondment to the Australian Research Council as Executive Director, Mathematics, Information and Communication Sciences. His notable publications include works on optimization algorithms exploiting unitary constraints and stochastic algorithms for networked agents with noisy measurements. Professor Manton has also been honored with a prestigious Queen Elizabeth II Fellowship and a Future Summit Australian Leadership Award.
results.search_notes: Found detailed information on Professor Manton's research areas, publications, and academic background from the Australian National University website.

results.name: Prof Jonathan Roberts
results.summary: Professor Jonathan Roberts is a leading expert in robotics, currently serving as a Professor in Robotics at Queensland University of Technology (QUT). His research focuses on field robotics, medical robotics, performance robotics, and design robotics. He has held significant positions, including Director of the Australian Cobotics Centre and Technical Director of the Advanced Robotics for Manufacturing (ARM) Hub. Notably, he co-invented the UAV Challenge Outback Rescue, an international flying robot competition, and was featured on BBC International News in 2014 and 2016 discussing the event. Additionally, in 2013, he was awarded the Australia and New Zealand Internet Award for Innovation for the Museum Robot Project, which deployed mobile robots in the National Museum of Australia to facilitate remote school visits. In 2013, he also made international news by being the first person to 3D map the interior of the Leaning Tower of Pisa using his team's Zebedee mobile mapping system. ([research.qut.edu.au](https://research.qut.edu.au/qcr/people/jonathan-roberts/?utm_source=openai))
results.search_notes: Comprehensive information about Professor Jonathan Roberts' research areas, publications, and career highlights was found through multiple reputable sources.

results.name: Prof Jonathan Woodhead
results.summary: Prof. Jon Woodhead is an Australian Laureate Fellow and Professor Emeritus at the University of Melbourne. He co-founded the Melbourne University Isotope Geochemistry group in the mid-1990s, which has grown into a major research team within the School of Geography, Earth and Atmospheric Sciences. ([isotopegeoscience.org](https://www.isotopegeoscience.org/about-us?utm_source=openai)) His research focuses on isotope geochemistry, particularly in the areas of geochronology and petrogenesis. He has co-authored numerous peer-reviewed publications, including studies on the petrogenesis of granitoids from the Lachlan Fold Belt and the role of disequilibrium melting. ([isotopegeoscience.org](https://www.isotopegeoscience.org/publications?utm_source=openai))
results.search_notes: Information about Prof. Jon Woodhead's research areas, publications, and career highlights was found through the Melbourne University Isotope Geochemistry group's website and their publications list.

He has an extensive publication record with over 100 journal articles and has been recognized with an ARC Future Fellowship in 2017.

His research interests encompass mechanisms of antigen presentation, development and function of dendritic cells, and anti-viral immunity.

results.name: Prof Joseph Monaghan

results.name: Prof Julie Cairney
results.summary: Professor Julie Cairney is an Australian engineer and materials researcher specializing in microstructural characterization and materials science. Her research focuses on understanding and characterizing materials used in structural applications, renewable energy, medical science, and geosciences, particularly through the use and development of the atom probe microscope. She has been recognized as one of the world's most influential researchers in her field, with over 200 publications cited more than 4,000 times. results.name: Prof Junwei Lu
results.summary: Professor Junwei Lu is a Foundation Professor in the School of Engineering and Built Environment at Griffith University, specializing in electrical and electronic engineering. His research focuses on high-frequency magnetics for power electronics and renewable energy systems, computational electromagnetics, and electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) computer modeling and simulation. He has been involved in various research projects, including the development of advanced microgrids for residential, commercial, and industrial buildings, and has received funding from the Australian Research Council Linkage Projects. Additionally, he has contributed to the development of low-cost and high-performance energy storage systems and wireless power transfer technologies for electric vehicles and automated guided vehicles. He holds an electrical engineering degree from Xian Jiaotong University, China, a Master of Engineering in electronic and computer engineering from National Toyama University, Japan, and a PhD in electrical and computer engineering from National Kanazawa University, Japan. He has been a member of the electrical power industry in China and has been with Griffith University since 1992, becoming a Foundation Professor in 2011. He is also a Life Senior Member of IEEE and has served as the chairman of the Queensland IEEE chapter of Power Electronics/Industry Electronics/Industry and as a Board Member of the International Compumag Society.
research_areas: High-frequency magnetics for power electronics and renewable energy systems
Electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) computer modeling and simulation

results.name: Prof Jürgen Götz
results.summary: Professor Jürgen Götz is a prominent researcher in the field of dementia, particularly Alzheimer's disease. He is the Lesleigh Green - Bill and Nancy Green Endowed Chair in Dementia Research and Director of the Clem Jones Centre for Ageing Dementia Research at the Queensland Brain Institute, University of Queensland. His research focuses on understanding the cellular and molecular mechanisms of neurodegeneration and developing novel therapeutic approaches, including the use of low-intensity ultrasound as a treatment modality for Alzheimer's disease and other brain diseases. He has published over 230 papers in leading journals such as Cell, Science, and Neuron, and has authored numerous reviews in the Nature Reviews journal family. In 2025, he was elected as a Fellow of the Australian Academy of Science for his significant contributions to dementia research. results.summary: Professor Kate Quinlan is a faculty member at the University of New South Wales (UNSW) in Australia, specializing in gene regulation and metabolism. results.name: Prof Mats Andersson
results.summary: Professor Mats Andersson is a Matthew Flinders Fellow and Director of Flinders Nanotechnology at Flinders University. His research focuses on the structure-property relationships of organic materials, aiming to design and synthesize new conjugated polymers for efficient and stable electronics such as solar cells, photodiodes, light-emitting diodes, electrochemical devices, and sensors. He has an extensive academic background, including a PhD in Organic Chemistry from Chalmers University of Technology in Sweden and a postdoctoral fellowship at the University of California, Santa Barbara. He has received several honors, including the Arrhenius medal from the Swedish Chemical Society in 2011 and election to the Royal Swedish Academy of Engineering Sciences in 2012. In 2013, he was awarded a South Australian Chair in Energy, and in 2017, he joined Flinders University as a Matthew Flinders Fellow. His work contributes to the UN Sustainable Development Goals, particularly in the areas of affordable and clean energy, industry innovation, and sustainable cities and communities.

results.name: Prof Nathaniel Bindoff

results.name: Prof Nerina Jimmieson
results.summary: Professor Nerina Jimmieson is a distinguished academic affiliated with the Queensland University of Technology (QUT), where she serves as a Professor in the Faculty of Business & Law, School of Management. Her research focuses on occupational stress, employee health, and organizational change management, employing methodologies such as laboratory-based task simulations, organizational surveys, diary studies, and interviews. She has authored over 120 publications, including journal articles and book chapters, and has secured more than $5 million in competitive and commercial funding for her research. Notably, she held an Australian Research Council Future Fellowship from 2012 to 2015 for a project titled 'Supervisor strategies for managing employee stress and strain: A national approach to psychosocial risk management.' In 2025, she became a Chief Investigator with the ARC Industrial Transformation Research Hub for Human-Robot Teaming for Sustainable and Resilient Construction, focusing on the psychosocial benefits and risks associated with deploying human-robot teams in construction workplaces. ([qut.edu.au](https://www.qut.edu.au/about/our-people/academic-profiles/n.jimmieson?utm_source=openai))

results.name: Prof Nicholas Haslam
results.summary: Prof. Nick Haslam is a social psychologist and Professor of Psychology at the University of Melbourne. He has taught and written extensively in the fields of clinical and social psychology, with a longstanding focus on psychiatric classification. He has a MA and PhD from the University of Pennsylvania, and taught at the New School for Social Research in New York City before returning to Australia in 2002. ([advance-he.ac.uk](https://www.advance-he.ac.uk/profile/prof-nick-haslam?utm_source=openai))
results.search_notes: Prof. Nick Haslam is a social psychologist and Professor of Psychology at the University of Melbourne. He has taught and written extensively in the fields of clinical and social psychology, with a longstanding focus on psychiatric classification. He has a MA and PhD from the University of Pennsylvania, and taught at the New School for Social Research in New York City before returning to Australia in 2002. ([advance-he.ac.uk](https://www.advance-he.ac.uk/profile/prof-nick-haslam?utm_source=openai)) His research interests include personality, social, and clinical psychology, and he has published 11 books and more than 300 articles or book chapters in these and related areas. ([psychologicalsciences.unimelb.edu.au](https://psychologicalsciences.unimelb.edu.au/research/msps-research-groups/social-personality-laboratory?utm_source=openai)) He is a leader in the social psychology group and co-director of the Mental Health PhD program at the University of Melbourne. ([advance-he.ac.uk](https://www.advance-he.ac.uk/profile/prof-nick-haslam?utm_source=openai)) He has previously served as Head of the School of Psychological Sciences, Pro Vice-Chancellor (Graduate), a member of the ARC College of Experts, and President of the Society of Australasian Social Psychologists. ([psychologicalsciences.unimelb.edu.au](https://psychologicalsciences.unimelb.edu.au/research/msps-research-groups/social-personality-laboratory?utm_source=openai)) His recent work includes a study on the changing meanings of 'anxiety' and 'depression' in academic and everyday language, published in July 2023. ([pursuit.unimelb.edu.au](https://pursuit.unimelb.edu.au/articles/do-we-think-about-anxiety-and-depression-differently-now?utm_source=openai)) He has also co-authored a paper titled 'The Neuroscientification of Psychology: The Rising Prevalence of Neuroscientific Concepts in Psychology From 1965 to 2016', published in 2022. ([journals.sagepub.com](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/1745691621991864?utm_source=openai)) Additionally, he has been recognized with the Research.com Psychology in Australia Leader Award in 2023 and 2024. results.name: Prof Nick Birbilis
affiliations: The University of New South Wales
results.summary: Professor Nick Birbilis is an Australian materials engineer and academic, currently serving as the Executive Dean of the Faculty of Science, Engineering, and Built Environment at Deakin University. He has made significant contributions to materials science, particularly in corrosion science, materials durability, and alloy design. results.name: Prof Nick Spencer
results.summary: Professor Nick Spencer is a Matthew Flinders Professor in the College of Medicine and Public Health at Flinders University. His research focuses on the neurophysiological basis of pain pathways in visceral organs and the neural control mechanisms of the enteric nervous system. He has published over 200 peer-reviewed papers on the neural control of the gastrointestinal tract and gut-brain axis, with recent publications in journals such as Cell, Nature Neuroscience, Neuron, eLife, and Gastroenterology. He has been a chief investigator on 15 NH&MRC project grants and 5 ARC Discovery grants, totaling over $10 million AUD. Notable achievements include the first wireless optogenetic control of the gut in freely moving animals, published in Gastroenterology in 2018, and the identification of vagal afferent nerve endings in the mouse colon, published in Cell and Tissue Research in 2024. He was elected President of the Australasian Neurogastroenterology & Motility Association in 2016 and served as Chair of Optogenetics Australia from 2022 to 2024. In 2024, he was elected Fellow of the International Union of Physiological Sciences. He completed his BSc(Hons) and PhD in Neurophysiology at Monash University in 1998 and has held positions at The University of Nevada School of Medicine before joining Flinders University in 2007.
results.search_notes: Comprehensive information about Professor Nick Spencer's research areas, publications, and career highlights was found through the provided sources.

results.name: Prof Peter Forrester
results.summary: Professor Peter Forrester is a world expert on random matrix theory and related areas of mathematics, including the occurrence of identities of the Rogers-Ramanujan type in exactly solvable statistical mechanical lattice models. He has applied the theory of Selberg integrals, generalized hypergeometric functions, and Jack polynomials to the integrable l/r² quantum many-body problem, obtaining perfect agreement with the new physical interpretation in terms of quasi-particle statistics. This enabled Forrester to successfully apply the theory of Painlevé equations to the very active topic of random matrix theory, with its relevance to the Riemann hypothesis and to the statistical analysis of large data sets. ([science.org.au](https://www.science.org.au/profile/peter-forrester?utm_source=openai))
results.search_notes: Found detailed information on Professor Forrester's research areas and achievements, including his election to the Australian Academy of Science in 2004 and his work on random matrix theory and statistical mechanics. results.name: Prof Peter Robinson
results.summary: Professor Peter Robinson is an Australian physicist specializing in complex systems, brain dynamics, and sleep modeling. He holds an ARC Federation Fellowship and is a Professor in the School of Physics at the University of Sydney. He is also the Deputy Director of the Brain Dynamics Center at the Westmead Millennium Institute and the Research Director of the University's Center for Waves and Complex Systems. His research interests include complex systems, brain dynamics, sleep modeling, computational neuroscience, biological physics, plasma and space physics, and other areas of theoretical and computational physics. He has developed and tested quantitative models of brain dynamics underlying observed brain activity in normal sleep and wake states, epilepsy, and Parkinson’s disease. His work on modeling brain activity is being used commercially by the listed spinoff company Brain Resource Ltd. In other areas, he is recognized for his contributions to nonlinear and stochastic processes in plasmas and is a Chief Investigator on the STEREO spacecraft mission. He has published nearly 300 refereed articles in various areas, including nearly 100 in biological physics. Some key articles in the areas of brain dynamics and sleep dynamics are: Robinson, P. A., et al., Phys. Rev. E, 56, 826 (1997); Robinson, P. A., et al., Phys. Rev. E, 65, 041924 (2002); Robinson, P. A., et al., Hum. Brain Mapp., 23, 53 (2004); Breakspear, M., et al., Cerebral Cortex, 16, 1296 (2006); Robinson, P. A., et al., NeuroImage, 31, 585 (2006); Phillips, A. J.K., and Robinson, P. A., J. Biol. Rhythms, 22, 167 (2007); Deco, G., et al., PLoS – Comp. Biol., e1000092 (2008); Phillips, A. J. K., and Robinson, P. A., J. Theor. Biol., 255, 413 (2008); van Albada, S. J., and Robinson, P. A., J. Theor. Biol., 257, 642 (2009); Robinson, P. A., et al., Phys. Rev. Lett., 103, 108104 (2009).

He has also been recognized with multiple Excellence Awards from the National Health and Medical Research Council and was named the leading researcher in cell biology in Australia by The Australian in 2020.

He has developed advanced DNA sequencing techniques to map the epigenome in various organisms, including plants, animals, and humans. His work has significantly advanced our understanding of genome regulation, stem cell biology, and brain development.
results.search_notes: Found comprehensive information on Professor Lister's research areas, recent publications, and career highlights.

results.name: Prof Ryan Lowe
results.summary: Professor Ryan Lowe is a coastal oceanographer at the University of Western Australia, specializing in the study of physical drivers of coastal processes and hazards. His research focuses on understanding how nearshore processes govern coastal flooding and erosion risks, and developing novel solutions to mitigate these hazards, particularly through the integration of natural and nature-based features. He has published over 130 papers in international journals and has contributed to international initiatives advancing nature-based solutions for coastal protection.
research_areas: Numerical modelling of waves and coastal circulation
results.search_notes: Comprehensive information about Professor Lowe's research areas, publications, and academic background was found across multiple reputable sources.

results.name: Prof S. Ole Warnaar
results.summary: Professor Ole Warnaar is a Chair and Professor of Pure Mathematics at the University of Queensland's School of Mathematics and Physics. He specializes in algebraic combinatorics, special functions, and partition theory, and has been recognized with the 2020 George Szekeres Medal for his contributions to the mathematical sciences. He has also served as the Editor-in-Chief of the Journal of Combinatorial Theory, Series A, and was elected to the Australian Academy of Science in 2008.
results.search_notes: Information about Professor Warnaar's research areas, recent publications, and career highlights was found through the provided sources.

results.name: Prof Salil Kanhere
affiliations: The University of New South Wales
results.summary: Professor Salil Kanhere is a distinguished academic affiliated with the University of New South Wales (UNSW) in Sydney, Australia. He has been recognized for his significant contributions to computing, including being named an ACM Distinguished Member in 2022. His research spans areas such as cybersecurity, distributed computing, cyber-physical and IoT systems, and pervasive computing, with over 300 peer-reviewed articles and 8 Best Paper Awards to his name. He has also co-authored the book 'Blockchain for Cyberphysical Systems' and received the Friedrich Wilhelm Bessel Research Award in 2020. Additionally, he serves as the Editor-in-Chief of the Ad Hoc Networks journal and holds associate editor positions for several IEEE journals. Her work spanned areas from consciousness to applications in decision-making, aging, and mental health.

([stories.uq.edu.au](https://stories.uq.edu.au/research/all-creatures-great-very-very-small/index.html?utm_source=openai))

She has been recognized for her distinguished scholarship, including election to the Australian Academy of the Humanities in 2018. She is also the lead author of the book 'Japanese War Criminals: The Politics of Justice After the Second World War,' which won the General History category in the New South Wales Premier’s Award for History in 2017.

results.name: Prof Sara Charlesworth
affiliations: The University of New South Wales
results.summary: Professor Sara Charlesworth is a socio-legal scholar specializing in gender equality in employment, focusing on labor markets, industry, and organizational levels. She has held two Australian Research Council fellowships, including a Future Fellowship from 2013 to 2018, and has been involved in several ARC projects addressing topics such as sexual harassment, gender equality, decent work, quality part-time work, work-life balance, and gender-equitable organizational change in male-dominated organizations. Her recent research has concentrated on low-paid work in feminized industries and paid care work. She has been an advisor to the Australian Human Rights Commission on their National Sexual Harassment Prevalence Surveys in 2012, 2018, and 2022, and has provided expert evidence to various state and federal Parliamentary committees and the Fair Work Commission on low-paid feminized work. ([rmit.edu.au](https://www.rmit.edu.au/contact/staff-contacts/academic-staff/c/charlesworth-emeritus-professor-sara?utm_source=openai))

results.name: Prof Sara Davies
results.summary: Professor Sara E. Davies is a distinguished scholar in International Relations, focusing on global health governance and the prevention of sexual and gender-based violence in conflict situations. She holds a professorship at Griffith University and serves as Deputy Director (Indo-Pacific Research) of the Australian Research Council Centre of Excellence for the Elimination of Violence Against Women. Her recent work includes leading the Context Pillar at Griffith's Griffith Asia Institute and co-leading the Impact of Shocks on Violence Against Women workstream for the Centre of Excellence. She has been recognized with an Australian Research Council Future Fellowship and elected as a Fellow of the Academy of the Social Sciences in Australia. Additionally, she is an Adjunct Associate Professor at Monash University and has contributed to the Asia-Pacific Centre for the Responsibility to Protect at the University of Queensland. Her research emphasizes the political conditions leading to human insecurity, particularly in contexts of disease outbreaks, gender-based and sexual violence in conflict, and forced displacement. She has co-authored works such as 'Disease Diplomacy' and has been involved in significant projects like the Australian Research Council Centre of Excellence for the Elimination of Violence Against Women. Her contributions have been recognized with an Australian Research Council Future Fellowship and her election as a Fellow of the Academy of the Social Sciences in Australia. ([cevaw.org](https://cevaw.org/cevaw_people/sara-e-davies/?utm_source=openai), [nationaltribune.com.au](https://www.nationaltribune.com.au/university-academics-join-academy-of-social-sciences/?utm_source=openai), [research.qut.edu.au](https://research.qut.edu.au/achlr/our-people/sara-davies/?utm_source=openai))
research_areas: prevention of sexual and gender-based violence in conflict situations
human insecurity in contexts of disease outbreaks and forced displacement
